  â
{{merge|2010â2011 Tunisian revolution|date=February 2011}}
  â   â
'''Jasmine Revolution''' relates to the pro-democratic protests for change in government in several countries<ref>{{cite web|author=February 20, 2011 | Dean Takahashi |url=http://venturebeat.com/2011/02/20/arab-revolts-another-good-week-for-social-media-a-bad-week-for-dictators/ |title=Arab revolts: Another good week for social media, a bad week for dictators |publisher=VentureBeat |date=2011-02-19 |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref><ref name="businessinsider1">{{cite web|author=DK Matai, mi2g | Feb. 22, 2011, 8:44 AM | 294 | |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/seeds-of-revolution-spread-in-middle-east-and-china-tweet-digest-and-expert-roundtables-2011-2 |title=Are The Seeds Of Revolution Spreading Throughout The Middle-East And China? |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-23}}</ref> including [[Tunisia]], [[Egypt]], [[China]], [[Libya]], [[Bahrain]], [[Morocco]], [[Gabon]], [[Algeria]], [[Iran]] and several other countries in year 2010-2011.
  â   â
==Origin==
  â   â
In Tunisia these protests are called the '''Sidi Bouzid Revolt''', derived from [[Sidi Bouzid]], the city where the initial protests began. <ref name="SidiBouzid_libcom">{{cite web|url=http://libcom.org/forums/news/protests-spread-tunisia-29122010 |title=The Sidi Bouzid Revolution: Ben Ali flees as protests spread in Tunisia |publisher=libcom.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="SidiBouzid_YT">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8thJM2nmd_g&feature=related |title=Revolte Tunisie Sidi bouzid 3 |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-01-04 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> The events have been dubbed in the media as the Jasmine Revolution<ref name="europe1.fr">{{cite web|author=Par FrÃ©dÃ©ric Frangeul |url=http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ |title=DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ? |publisher=Europe1.fr |date=2011-01-19 |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">[http://www.europe1.fr/International/D-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743/ DâoÃ¹ vient la "rÃ©volution du jasmin" ?] Europe1.fr International, 17 january 2011 ([http://translate.google.com/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=en&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=auto&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.europe1.fr%2FInternational%2FD-ou-vient-la-revolution-du-jasmin-375743%2F Google Translate version])</ref> in keeping with the geopolitical nomenclature of "[[color revolutions]]", although the comparison is disputed, notably by many Tunisians themselves.<ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.lemonde.fr%2Fafrique%2Farticle%2F2011%2F01%2F17%2Frevolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="translate.google.com">{{cite web|url=http://translate.google.fr/translate?js=n&prev=_t&hl=fr&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&sl=fr&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mediapart.fr%2Fclub%2Fblog%2Folivier-malaponti%2F150111%2Frevolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=Google Translate |language={{fr icon}} |publisher=Translate.google.fr |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref name="Le Monde">{{cite web|url=http://www.lemonde.fr/afrique/article/2011/01/17/revolution-du-jasmin-une-expression-qui-ne-fait-pas-l-unanimite_1466871_3212.html/ |title="RÃ©volution du jasmin" : une expression qui ne fait pas l'unanimitÃ© |publisher=LeMonde.fr |date=2011-01-17 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref name="Mediapart">{{cite web|author=Olivier Malaponti |url=http://www.mediapart.fr/club/blog/olivier-malaponti/150111/revolution-de-jasmin-0 |title=RÃ©volution de jasmin ? |publisher=Mediapart.fr |date=2011-01-15 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
  â   â
==Impact of the internet==
  â   â
The use of communication technologies, and the Internet in particular, has been widely credited as contributor to the mobilisation of protests.<ref>[http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/ Threat Level] Wired</ref> A blog associated with [[Wired]] described the intricate efforts of the Tunisian authorities to control such online media as<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/threatlevel/2011/01/tunisia/|title=Tweeting Tyrants Out of Tunisia: Global Internet at Its Best|publisher=Threat Level / Wired}}</ref> ''Twitter'' and ''Facebook''. Other regional regimes were also on higher alert to contain spillover effects that may ensue.
  â   â
